msDesc.physDesc: This letter is one page long. The heading is “Miss Harriet Monroe, “Poetry” 543 Cass St., Chicago, Ill.”. There is a handwritten “4” which covers an indecipherable number in “543 Cass St.”. The year has a handwritten “1” before the 8, indicating it was 1918. The letter is typed on plain white paper; it is not creased.

div.p: Thank you very much for the little joke, which I enjoyed immensely. I wonder who the anonymous English authors are who sent it to you. As to the re-printing of “Appuldurcombe Park” in “The Evening Journal,” I am very much pleased to think that they felt like doing it. From what you say, I suppose it is your friend, Miss Birch, who is responsible. William Carlos Williams wrote me a most enthusiastic letter about it, at which I was greatly astonished. Altogether, it seems to be doing well. I trust you got my book safely which I sent you the other day. I know you are not stuck on polyphonic prose, but I trust that there is something in it which you will like. You will probably have received the advertisement by now, because it was in the list of advertisements which Macmillan sent me the other day. I am still stuck to my bed, but your having told me not to worry about that makes the sticking less undesirable. As I feel perfectly well, it is annoying, but the doctor assures me that when he does let me up, I will be entirely well. At any rate, he found that the operation was much more necessary than they had anticipated. I was on the operating table one hour and twenty minutes, therefore, I am reconciled, although, I confess, I find this enforced illness a bit trying. Affectionately yours,
